sub_topic: Show that every group of order 10 is isomorphic to either the cyclic group C10, the dihedral group D5, or the non-abelian group of order 10.
message_1: Let G be a group of order 10, show that G is isomorphic to either C10, D5, or the non-abelian group of order 10. Identify which group G is isomorphic to.
message_2:
To show that G is isomorphic to either C10, D5, or the non-abelian group of order 10, we will use the Sylow theorems and analyze the possible structures of G.

Since the order of G is 10, we have |G| = 2 * 5. By the Sylow theorems, we know that there exist Sylow 2-subgroups and Sylow 5-subgroups in G. Let P2 and P5 be the Sylow 2-subgroup and Sylow 5-subgroup of G, respectively. Then, |P2| = 2 and |P5| = 5.

By the Sylow theorems, the number of Sylow 2-subgroups, n2, divides 5 and is congruent to 1 mod 2. Thus, n2 = 1 or n2 = 5. Similarly, the number of Sylow 5-subgroups, n5, divides 2 and is congruent to 1 mod 5. Thus, n5 = 1.

If n2 = 1, then there is a unique Sylow 2-subgroup P2, which is normal in G. Since P5 is also normal in G, we have that G is the internal direct product of P2 and P5. Since P2 and P5 have relatively prime orders, G is isomorphic to the external direct product of P2 and P5, which is C2 × C5. Since C2 × C5 is isomorphic to C10, G is isomorphic to C10 in this case.

If n2 = 5, then there are 5 Sylow 2-subgroups in G. Let H be one of these Sylow 2-subgroups. Since |G| = 10 and |H| = 2, the index of H in G is [G : H] = 5. By the orbit-stabilizer theorem, the action of G on the set of left cosets of H by left multiplication is isomorphic to a subgroup of S5. Since the order of G is 10, this subgroup must be isomorphic to either D5 or the non-abelian group of order 10.

If G is abelian, then G must be isomorphic to C10, as we showed earlier. If G is non-abelian, then G is isomorphic to either D5 or the non-abelian group of order 10. To determine which one, we can look at the structure of G. If G has an element of order 10, then G is isomorphic to C10. If G has no element of order 10 but has an element of order 5 and an element of order 2, then G is isomorphic to D5. If G has no element of order 10 and no element of order 5, then G is isomorphic to the non-abelian group of order 10.

In conclusion, G is isomorphic to either C10, D5, or the non-abelian group of order 10. To identify which group G is isomorphic to, we need more information about the structure of G.
